questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of an episode of syncope 2 hours ago. He reports sudden onset of palpitations followed by loss of consciousness while carrying his groceries to his car. He is unable to recall any further details and does not have any chest pain or dizziness. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, gastroparesis, and osteoarthritis of the knees. Medications include lisinopril, metformin, and ondansetron as needed for nausea. He also takes methadone daily for chronic pain. Apart from an abrasion on his forehead, he appears well. His temperature is 37.2 °C (98.9 F), pulse is 104/min and regular, and blood pressure is 135/70 mm Hg. While he is in the emergency department, he loses consciousness again. Telemetry shows polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with cyclic alteration of the QRS axis that spontaneously resolves after 30 seconds. Results of a complete blood count, serum electrolyte concentrations, and serum thyroid studies show no abnormalities. Cardiac enzymes are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's syncope?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A prolonged QT interval may be congenital or acquired, and typically remains asymptomatic until patients present with syncope or life-threatening arrhythmias such as TdP. Acquired prolongation of the QT interval can be caused by certain medications (e.g., amiodarone, methadone, ondansetron) or electrolyte imbalances (e.g., hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia). This patient's history of ondansetron and methadone therapy makes drug-induced QT prolongation that progressed to TdP the most likely cause of his syncope. Treatment consists of administering magnesium sulfate regardless of baseline magnesium levels.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Regular ectopic atrial rhythm: negative P-waves in II and aVF (normally positive), positive P-waves in aVR (normally negative) and V1 (normally biphasic) (examples indicated by blue overlay)
- Heart rate of approx. 75/min
- Normal cardiac axis
- Normal PR interval (approx. 120 ms), normal QRS duration (approx. 80 ms)
- Prolonged QT interval (QTc approx. 580 ms, example indicated by red overlay)
- Ventricular extrasystoles seen in leads I to III

B) INCORRECT:

Acute myocardial ischemia can manifest with syncope and, in some cases, ventricular tachyarrhythmia, which is seen in this patient with risk factors for coronary artery disease (diabetes mellitus and hypertension). However, he lacks other typical features of acute myocardial ischemia, such as chest pain, lasting ECG changes (e.g., ST changes), and elevated cardiac enzymes.

C) INCORRECT:

A shortened PR interval can be seen in preexcitation syndromes such as Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) and Lown-Ganong-Levine (LGL) syndrome. While these conditions can also manifest with syncope, this patient lacks the characteristic findings of WPW syndrome (i.e., short PR interval, slurring and slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex, and widened QRS complex) or LGL syndrome (i.e., short PR interval with normal QRS complexes). Instead, TdP is seen, which is not a feature of these conditions. Both WPW and LGL syndrome cause atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia but not ventricular tachycardias like TdP.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)

A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

D) INCORRECT:

A fast accessory conduction pathway can be seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, which can manifest with palpitation and syncope. However, typical ECG findings include a shortened PR interval (< 120 ms), slurring and slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave), and a widened QRS complex. WPW syndrome causes atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia but not ventricular tachycardias such as TdP.
Image Description:

Conduction pathways and characteristic ECG findings in normal impulse transmission and in WPW syndrome. Note that the condition is referred to as WPW syndrome only if the characteristic ECG findings are present and the patient is also symptomatic or there is evidence of arrhythmia; if the characteristic ECG findings are present without these additional features, the condition is referred to as “WPW pattern.”

Left (normal impulse transmission and normal ECG findings): PR interval 120–200 ms; QRS duration < 100 ms

Right (WPW impulse transmission and characteristic ECG findings): short PR interval < 120 ms; slurred upstroke (delta wave) at the start of the QRS complex with widened QRS ≥ 120 ms

E) INCORRECT:

Prinzmetal angina can lead to ventricular arrhythmias that can manifest with syncope and reversible ECG changes. However, this condition typically manifests with recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain or pressure radiating to the neck, jaw, left shoulder, or arm.

F) INCORRECT:

Brugada syndrome can manifest with syncope and ventricular tachyarrhythmia. However, characteristic ECG findings include incomplete right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevations in the anterior precordial leads.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 50 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼83/min
– Right axis deviation: R < S in I, R > S in aVF
– ST elevation ≥ 2 mm and a negative T wave in V1 and V2 (red overlay). The shape of ST elevation seen in V1 is described as “coved.”
– Pseudo-RBBB: The ST changes create a pattern resembling RBBB in V1.

Pseudo-RBBB with ST elevation in V1–V3 is characteristic of Brugada pattern. To diagnose Brugada syndrome, the corresponding clinical criteria must also be met, e.g., VF, syncope, or pertinent family history.

G) INCORRECT:

Hypomagnesemia is a predisposing factor for TdP. However, this patient has no risk factors for hypomagnesemia (e.g., diarrhea, alcoholism, use of diuretics) and lacks other typical features of hypomagnesemia such as neuromuscular manifestations (e.g., tetany, seizures).
questions.hint: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with cyclic alteration of the QRS axis (sinusoidal waveform) is referred to as torsades de pointes (TdP) and can progress to life-threatening ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. She feels well and wants to discuss pausing her only current medication, flecainide. Her pulse is 75/min and regular, blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a PR interval of 180 ms, QRS time of 120 ms, and corrected QT interval of 440 ms. Which of the following ECG changes is most likely to be seen on cardiac stress testing in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prolongation of the QTc interval is a possible ECG change seen on cardiac stress testing in patients taking class IA and class III antiarrhythmic drugs, which block potassium channels, resulting in a prolonged repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential. Flecainide has minimal effects on the ventricular repolarization but can result in shortening (rather than prolongation) of the QTc interval on stress testing.

Class IC antiarrhythmic drugs such as flecainide may prolong the uncorrected QT interval, which may predispose to ventricular tachyarrhythmias (e.g., torsade de pointes), especially in patients with structural heart disease, electrolyte disturbances, or coronary artery disease.

B) INCORRECT:

False-positive ST-segment depression is a possible ECG change seen on cardiac stress testing in patients taking digoxin. Flecainide has only very rarely been associated with false-positive ST-segment depression.

C) INCORRECT:

Class I antiarrhythmic drugs act by blocking the sodium channels in cardiomyocytes, which results in prolongation of the PR interval, not shortening. In patients taking flecainide, first- and second-degree AV block may be seen on cardiac stress testing.

D) CORRECT:

Class I antiarrhythmic drugs such as flecainide block the fast sodium channels responsible for phase 0 of the myocardial action potential (rapid upstroke and depolarization). The effect is an action potential with decreased slope and amplitude, which prolongs the spread of depolarization to neighboring cells, slowing conduction through the myocardium. Since phase 0 for ventricular myocytes corresponds to the QRS complex on ECG, flecainide prolongs the QRS complex. This particular effect of class I antiarrhythmic drugs, especially of class IC antiarrhythmic drugs, is use/state-dependent, i.e., it increases with the heart rate (e.g., during cardiac stress testing), as more sodium channels are recruited for cardiac contraction.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased maximal heart rate is an ECG change typically seen on cardiac stress testing in patients taking beta blockers. Beta blockers inhibit the influence of the sympathetic nervous system on cardiac electrical activity, causing negative chronotropic, inotropic, and dromotropic effects that result in decreased heart rate, decreased cardiac contractility, and decreased conduction (especially at the AV node), respectively.

Flecainide may also have a limiting effect on the maximal heart rate, but a different ECG change is much more common.
questions.hint: Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic used in patients with paroxysmal supraventricular arrhythmias and no other structural heart disease. One of its cardinal features is use-dependence.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of anxiety, difficulty focusing on tasks, and a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 4 weeks. He is diaphoretic. His pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, moist skin, goiter, and a resting tremor of both hands. Laboratory studies show a thyroxine (T4) concentration of 30 μg/dL and a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 0.1 μU/mL. The patient is started on methimazole and atenolol. The latter agent predominantly affects which of the following?

choices.text: Effective refractory period of the cardiac action potential
Phase 0 depolarization slope of the cardiac action potential

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

β1 adrenergic receptor antagonists lower concentrations of cAMP and calcium in the cells of the atrioventricular (AV) node. This decreases conduction and automaticity at the AV node by decreasing the slope of phase 4 depolarization of the nodal (pacemaker) action potential. On ECG this effect would appear as a prolonged PR interval. Beta blockers also have a negative chronotropic (↓ risk of heart failure) and a negative inotropic (↓ contractility) effect.
Image Description:

Illustration of membrane potential of the atrioventricular node over time for class II antiarrhythmic drugs.

Normal action potential is shown faded. Class II antiarrhythmic drugs extend the time until the threshold potential is reached and prolong depolarization and are therefore negative dromotropic (slow down conduction speed).

B) INCORRECT:

Atenolol acts on β1 receptors to decrease sympathetic tone. It has no effect on vagal (parasympathetic) tone. Digoxin is an antiarrhythmic that can increase vagal tone.

C) INCORRECT:

Prolongation of the effective refractory period of the cardiac action potential is caused by Class IA, IC, III, and IV antiarrhythmic drugs. Beta-blockers (class II antiarrhythmics), however, do not significantly alter the refractory period.

D) INCORRECT:

Class I antiarrhythmics can decrease conduction in extranodal tissue (e.g., His-Purkinje system). Beta blockers do not act on the His-Purkinje system.

E) INCORRECT:

Phase 0 depolarization slope of the cardiac action potential is caused by the opening of fast voltage-gated Na+ channels. Class I antiarrhythmics, which block these channels, would, therefore, affect phase 0. Beta-blockers (class II antiarrhythmics) do not affect Na+ channel activity and do not have any effect on phase 0. They instead decrease the slope of phase 4 depolarization.
questions.hint: Atenolol is a cardioselective beta blocker, which competitively antagonizes the positive chronotropic, inotropic, and dromotropic effect of catecholamines.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effects of drugs on the cardiac action potential. Cardiomyocytes are infused with a pharmacological agent and incubated for 5 minutes, after which the action potential is registered on a graph in real time for 2 minutes. The black line represents an action potential following the infusion of the pharmacological agent. The results shown in the graph are most likely caused by an agent that inhibits which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels in cardiomyocytes prompts calcium influx, which, when coupled with potassium efflux, results in phase 2 (i.e., plateau phase) of the cardiac action potential. Calcium influx also prompts calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, causing ventricular contraction. Inhibiting the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels in cardiomyocytes would delay phase 2, not result in a slower phase 0, which is seen in this experiment.

L-type Ca2+ channels are responsible for the depolarization phase of cardiac pacemaker cells. These channels are the target of nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, which decrease heart rate by slowing pacemaker cell depolarization.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac myocytes have many types of voltage-gated potassium channels which open at different phases of the cardiac action potential. Voltage-gated potassium channels perform the initial repolarization of phase 1, balance calcium efflux in phase 2, cause repolarization in phase 3, and maintain resting membrane potential in phase 4. Potassium channels are not involved in phase 0 and thus would not cause the slowed phase 0 seen in this action potential.

C) INCORRECT:

Closure of voltage-gated sodium channels corresponds to the beginning of phase 1 of the cardiac action potential. The transient outward flow of potassium during this phase causes a partial membrane repolarization after the cardiac action potential peak. Inhibition of this step would not affect the slope of the initial upstroke of phase 0 as we see in this experiment. Instead, it would cause a higher spike and a delayed phase 1.

D) CORRECT:

Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels is the first event in the cardiac action potential. As sodium ions enter, the cell membrane rapidly depolarizes in phase 0 of the action potential. This experiment shows the effect of class IC antiarrhythmics, which slow opening of voltage-gated sodium channels and decrease the slope of phase 0 while still maintaining the AP duration. Class IC antiarrhythmics also exhibit use dependence, further decreasing the slope as heart rate increases. Although both class IA antiarrhythmics and IB antiarrhythmics also slow opening of voltage-gated sodium channels and decrease the slope of phase 0, they prolong and shorten the AP duration, respectively.
Image Description:

Resting potential (approx. -90mV) relies primarily on potassium channels (inward-rectifier potassium channels), ensuring a steady potassium efflux (iK1).

Phase 0 (depolarization): Neighboring cells stimulate voltage-gated sodium channels within the cell, causing them to open briefly. This results in a sodium influx (iNa ), and, consequently, the membrane potential increases just beyond 0 mV (overshoot).

Phase 1 (partial repolarization): The brief influx of chloride and efflux of potassium (not shown here) causes membrane potential to decrease.

Phase 2 (plateau): The opening of voltage-gated L-type calcium channels causes an influx of calcium ions (iCa), counteracting the repolarization and keeping the membrane potential at approximately 0mV.

Phase 3 (repolarization): Rapid repolarization occurs via the opening of outward-rectifier potassium channels, resulting in a net efflux of potassium.

Phase 4 (resting potential): A steady efflux of potassium (ik1) occurs until the cell is stimulated again and the process begins again at phase 0.

E) INCORRECT:

The closure of transient voltage-gated potassium channels marks the end of phase 1 and the beginning of phase 2. This ends the period of partial membrane repolarization and results in the plateauing of the membrane potential. Inhibiting the closure of transient voltage-gated potassium channels would not decrease the slope of phase 0 as seen in this action potential; instead, it would result in more dramatic repolarization in phase 1 and a delayed phase 2.

Voltage-gated potassium channels that cause repolarization in phase 3 are the target of class III antiarrhythmic drugs. These medications inhibit potassium efflux, prolonging phase 3 and phase 4.

F) INCORRECT:

The closure of voltage-gated calcium channels marks the beginning of phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. Although closure of these channels stops calcium influx, potassium efflux continues, resulting in repolarization as the voltage returns to resting membrane potential. Inhibition of this step would not have any effect on phase 0 as seen in this experiment, but would instead prolong phase 2.
questions.hint: The graph shows a ventricular action potential. The drug changes the duration of the rapid upstroke of the action potential (phase 0) without significantly changing the overall duration of the action potential.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother 30 minutes after the sudden onset of shortness of breath, dizziness, abdominal pain, and urticaria. The symptoms began 5 minutes after she ate a peanut butter sandwich. Her respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 84/50 mm Hg. There is stridor on auscultation of the chest. She is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and the appropriate pharmacotherapy are begun. The drug administered to this patient has which of the following effects on cardiac pacemaker cells during an action potential?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sympathetic stimulation (e.g., following epinephrine administration) increases the conductance of funny channels, thereby increasing Na+ influx in phase 4 (spontaneous depolarization) of the pacemaker action potential. This leads to more rapid depolarization, thereby increasing heart rate.

Epinephrine increases heart rate by stimulating beta-1 receptors. In patients with anaphylactic shock, epinephrine also leads to bronchial relaxation (easing breathing) via activation of beta-2 receptors and vasoconstriction (stabilizing blood pressure) through activation of alpha-1 receptors.
Image Description:

Depolarization:

Blue (if): Hyperpolarization triggers the opening of funny channels (if), resulting in an influx of cations into the cell and their depolarization to the threshold potential of -40 mV.

Violet (iCa): Voltage-gated calcium channels (iCa) open at approx. -40 mV, resulting in an influx of calcium cations into the cell and their depolarization to the threshold potential of approx. +20 mV.

Repolarization:

Green (iKs+Kr): The calcium channels close and the delayed outward rectifier potassium channels open (iKs+Kr). This causes an outflow of potassium ions out of the cell until it returns to -60 mV again. This leads to the closure of the potassium channels and the opening of funny channels, thus initiating a new excitation cycle.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased Na+ influx in phase 0 (upstroke) of the cardiac action potential would slow depolarization in the cardiac myocytes. It would not have an effect on pacemaker cells, as they rely on calcium (not sodium) channels during phase 0. Decreasing Na+ influx is the mechanism of action of class I antiarrhythmic agents, which are not used during anaphylactic shock.

C) INCORRECT:

During phase 3 of the pacemaker action potential (repolarization), the voltage-gated Ca2+ channels close, blocking the influx of Ca2+. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels mediate the influx of Ca2+ but not its efflux. During this phase, K+ channels open, allowing for K+ efflux, thereby leading to rapid repolarization.

D) INCORRECT:

At the threshold potential, the opening of additional L-type Ca2+ channels augments the inward current of calcium ions, resulting in the upstroke of phase 0 of the pacemaker action potential. Calcium channel blockers block L-type calcium channels, resulting in reduced Ca2+ influx during the late part of phase 4 and phase 0 of the pacemaker action potential. However, calcium channel blockers do not have a role in treatment of anaphylactic shock.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased K+ efflux in phase 4 leads to a decreased rate of spontaneous depolarization since cardiac myocytes become more electronegative and therefore require more cation influx to depolarize. Acetylcholine and adenosine both increase K+ efflux in phase 4 of the action potential. However, neither of these drugs are used in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased K+ efflux during phase 3 of the cardiac action potential leads to prolonged repolarization, extending the refractory period. This is the mechanism of action of class III antiarrhythmic drugs, which are not used to treat anaphylactic shock.
questions.hint: The onset of shortness of breath, hypotension, abdominal pain, urticaria, and angioedema shortly after ingestion of a commonly allergenic food (peanuts) is consistent with anaphylaxis. Epinephrine is the mainstay of pharmacotherapy for this condition.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and palpitations for 3 hours. He has had similar episodes intermittently for 4 months. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. An ECG shows irregular narrow-complex tachycardia with no discernable P waves. Emergent electrical cardioversion is performed and the patient reverts to normal sinus rhythm. Pharmacotherapy with sotalol is begun. Which of the following is the most likely physiologic effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Decreased AV nodal conduction is a potent effect of all beta blockers (class II antiarrhythmics), including sotalol. As a consequence of sympathetic blockade (primarily β1 receptors), the conduction velocity through the AV node is reduced and the heart rate slows. Decreased AV nodal conduction would be evident on ECG as an increased PR interval. Class III antiarrhythmic effects of sotalol include increased myocyte action potential duration (due to delayed repolarization caused by decreased K+ efflux), increased effective refractory period, and prolonged QT interval.

Decreased AV nodal conduction is also caused by non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (class IV antiarrhythmics), class IC antiarrhythmics (e.g., flecainide, propafenone), digoxin, and adenosine.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased ventricular repolarization rate is seen with class IB antiarrhythmics (e.g., lidocaine, mexiletine), which are typically used to treat ventricular arrhythmias in patients with myocardial infarction, and digitalis-induced arrhythmias. Class III antiarrhythmic drugs, which block potassium channels in cardiac myocytes, would decrease rather than increase the ventricular repolarization rate.
Image Description:

Compared to a unaffected action potential (faded line), the action potential of a myocardial cell affected by a Class IB antiarrhythmic has a slower phase 0 depolarization (decreased slope), and a shorter action potential duration (measured from resting potential to resting potential).

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased conduction in cardiac myocytes and Purkinje fibers is the mechanism by which sodium channel blockers (class I antiarrhythmics) function. By inhibiting the flow of sodium ions, the rapid depolarization phase (phase 0) of cardiac action potentials is slowed. Sotalol is not a class I antiarrhythmic and does not have a clinically apparent effect on conduction velocity in the Purkinje fibers.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased myocyte inotropy is caused by digoxin, which can be used to treat atrial fibrillation in patients with heart failure. Sotalol is an antiarrhythmic drug with the properties of a beta blocker (class II antiarrhythmic drug), and thus causes a decrease in inotropy.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperpolarization due to increased K+ efflux from myocytes is the mechanism of action of adenosine. Adenosine is used in the acute setting to terminate stable paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias (PSVT) such as AVNRT and AVRT, which are typically regular narrow complex tachycardias. Adenosine should not be used to treat atrial fibrillation (AF) because it worsens AF. This patient received sotalol, a class III antiarrhythmic drug, which would slow the rate of repolarization by decreasing K+ efflux from the myocyte.
questions.hint: Irregular narrow-complex tachycardia with no discernable P waves indicates atrial fibrillation. After multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation, this man was cardioverted and administered sotalol for continued rhythm control. Sotalol is a unique antiarrhythmic drug with both class II antiarrhythmic (beta blocker) and class III antiarrhythmic (potassium-channel blocker) properties.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with congestive heart failure is brought to the emergency department because of chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, and palpitations for 30 minutes. An ECG shows a wide complex tachycardia with a P-wave rate of 105/min, an R-wave rate of 130/min, and no apparent relation between the two. Intravenous pharmacotherapy is initiated with a drug that prolongs the QRS and QT intervals. The patient was most likely treated with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Verapamil is a class IV antiarrhythmic. These drugs are used for controlling ventricular rate in supraventricular tachycardia and act on calcium-dependent cardiac cells, such as those in the AV node. Class IV drugs reduce inward calcium current during the AP and phase 4. As a result, conduction velocity through the AV node is decreased and the refractory period is prolonged, which increases the PR interval. Verapamil does not have an effect on QRS or QT duration, though.

B) INCORRECT:

Carvedilol is a nonselective beta blocker/alpha 1 blocker and a class II antiarrhythmic. It blocks β1, β2, and α1 receptors on cardiac myocytes. The alpha blockade decreases peripheral vascular resistance, resulting in an antihypertensive effect. Beta inhibition leads to decreased heart rate (increased PR interval) and contractility. Carvedilol does not impact the QT interval or QRS duration.

C) INCORRECT:

Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic. While these drugs are powerful depressants of the sodium current, they have no effect on ventricular AP duration or the QT interval.

D) INCORRECT:

Lidocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic. While all class I drugs slow conduction through the fast-inward sodium current (INa), class IB drugs selectively affect ischemic or depolarized tissue. They have little effect on atrial tissue and do not reduce the Phase 3 potassium current (IK). This results in a shortened action potential duration but prolonged effective refractory period. These drugs would not be expected to increase the QRS duration or the QT interval.

E) INCORRECT:

Sotalol is generally classified as a class III antiarrhythmic drug but also has class II antiarrhythmic properties (β-blocking effect). The hallmark of class III is prolongation of the action potential duration by blockade of potassium channels (IK) that are responsible for repolarization. This results in PR and QT prolongation but not an increase in QRS duration. Other class III agents, such as amiodarone, do prolong both QRS and QT as a result of sodium, calcium, and potassium channel blockade as well as β adrenoceptors antagonism.

F) CORRECT:

Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic agent used to treat or prevent ventricular arrhythmias. All class I drugs slow conduction by blocking the voltage-gated sodium channels. This causes the phase 0 depolarization rate of the cardiac action potential to decrease. This occurs in a “use-dependent” fashion: at higher heart rates, the sodium channel block intensifies, while the opposite is true at lower heart rates. Class IA drugs also reduce phase 3 potassium current (IK) and prolong the effective refractory period. The overall effect of quinidine, as seen on this patient's ECG is prolongation of the QT and QRS durations.
questions.hint: The drug administered to this patient acts to block cardiac sodium channels and prolongs the action potential.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency room because of dizziness and palpitations for the past hour. His pulse is 185/min and blood pressure is 100/52 mm Hg. An ECG shows a narrow-complex, regular tachycardia without P waves. A drug is administered that activates cardiac potassium channels and causes transient atrioventricular block. Which of the following adverse effects is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe headache is a common side effect of nitrates (e.g., nitroglycerin, isosorbide dinitrate), which release nitric oxide in smooth muscle cells, resulting in vasodilation and increased intracranial pressure. Other side effects of nitrates include hypotension, reflex tachycardia, and syncope. Severe headaches are not a common side effect of adenosine, which this patient received.

B) INCORRECT:

Sedation is a known side effect of beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol, labetalol) and class IB antiarrhythmics (e.g., lidocaine, mexiletine). These agents are lipophilic and can penetrate the blood-brain barrier, resulting in CNS side effects. Adenosine does not cause sedation.

C) CORRECT:

Chest pain is a common adverse effect in patients treated with adenosine. Adenosine causes a transient atrioventricular (AV) block by increasing potassium efflux from cells, which causes hyperpolarization, decreased calcium influx, and decreased levels of intracellular cAMP. The brief AV block (usually < 15 secs) can cause chest pain and a feeling of impending doom. Other side effects of adenosine include hypotension, flushing, bronchospasm, bradycardia, and nausea. Prolonged asystole is rare but also a potential complication.

Theophylline and caffeine are adenosine receptor antagonists that can inhibit the effect of adenosine.

D) INCORRECT:

Dry cough is a side effect of ACE-inhibitors that results from decreased breakdown of bradykinin. This increases production of arachidonic acid metabolites (e.g., prostaglandins), which accumulate in the upper respiratory tract and the lungs, resulting in a dry cough. Adenosine can cause shortness of breath but not dry cough.

E) INCORRECT:

Perioral paresthesia is a side effect of lidocaine, a class IB antiarrhythmic agent used to treat ventricular tachycardia. When administered intravenously, lidocaine works by blocking the sodium channels in cardiac cells. Adenosine, which this patient received for his supraventricular arrhythmia, does not cause perioral paresthesia.

F) INCORRECT:

Blurry vision with a yellow tint and halos is a side effect of digoxin. Digoxin inhibits Na+/K+-ATPase and indirectly increases calcium in the cell, leading to increased cardiac contractility. Other side effects of digoxin include arrhythmias, kidney failure, hyperkalemia, and hypercalcemia. Yellow vision is not a known side effect of adenosine.
questions.hint: The patient has been given the antiarrhythmic drug adenosine.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of intermittent chest tightness that worsens with exercise. He has chronic atrial fibrillation treated with a drug that prolongs the QT interval. During cardiac stress testing, an ECG shows progressive shortening of the QT interval as the heart rate increases. Which of the following drugs is this patient most likely taking?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diltiazem is a class IV antiarrhythmic that is used for rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation. Class IV antiarrhythmic drugs inhibit slow calcium channels which mediate cardiac pacemaker depolarization. This inhibition decreases the ability of cardiac pacemaker cells to reach the threshold potential and decreases conduction velocity. As a result, the duration of the effective refractory period increases, which results in PR interval prolongation on ECG. Class IV antiarrhythmics do not affect the QT interval.

B) INCORRECT:

Lidocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic used to treat ventricular arrhythmias; it is not used to treat atrial fibrillation. Class IB antiarrhythmics block sodium channels in cardiac myocytes and shorten the duration of the action potential. They do not prolong the QT interval and may slightly shorten it. Moreover, while class IB antiarrhythmics exhibit some use-dependence, they do not exhibit reverse use-dependence.

C) INCORRECT:

Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic that is used to convert atrial fibrillation to sinus rhythm. Class IC antiarrhythmics block sodium channels in cardiac myocytes and prolong the duration of the effective refractory period in the atrioventricular node. Although this class of antiarrhythmics has little effect on ventricular repolarization, the QT interval is minimally prolonged due to the increase in the QRS duration. Moreover, flecainide exhibits use-dependence; in rare cases, there is a progressive prolonging of the QT interval on cardiac stress testing (i.e., as the heart rate increases) rather than the shortening of the QT interval seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Dofetilide is a class III antiarrhythmic that is used to maintain normal sinus rhythm in patients with chronic atrial fibrillation. Class III antiarrhythmics inhibit potassium channels which are responsible for repolarization of the cardiac membrane. Delayed repolarization prolongs the duration of the cardiac action potential and the effective refractory period, which results in QT interval prolongation on ECG. All class III antiarrhythmics, with the exception of amiodarone, exhibit reverse use-dependence, as seen during this patient's cardiac stress testing. Accordingly, these drugs have decreased antiarrhythmic effects at faster heart rates and are associated with the development of torsades de pointes at slower heart rates.

E) INCORRECT:

Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic that is used to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with atrial fibrillation. Class IA antiarrhythmics decrease sodium influx during depolarization and potassium efflux during repolarization. This activity prolongs the duration of the cardiac action potential and the effective refractory period, which results in QT interval prolongation on ECG. However, class IA antiarrhythmics exhibit use-dependence and thus cause progressive prolongation, not shortening, of the QT interval as the heart rate increases.

F) INCORRECT:

Carvedilol is a β-blocker and class II antiarrhythmic that is used for rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation. In the cardiac myocyte, β-adrenergic activation of adenylate cyclase results in the production of cAMP. This second messenger facilitates the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which leads to cardiac pacemaker depolarization. Class II antiarrhythmics decrease the conduction velocity of cardiac pacemaker cells, which results in PR interval prolongation on ECG. They do not affect the QT interval.
questions.hint: This patient is taking a drug that exhibits reverse use-dependence, a phenomenon in which the effects of an antiarrhythmic (e.g., QT interval prolongation for this drug) decrease as the heart rate increases.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of palpitations and dizziness. His pulse is 65/min and regular. An ECG is shown. A drug is administered that inhibits non-dihydropyridine calcium channels in the heart and his symptoms improve. The drug administered to the patient most likely has which of the following effects on the cardiac conduction system?

choices.text: Prolongation of Purkinje fiber refractory period
Decrease in bundle of His refractory period
Decrease in ventricular myocardial action potential duration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prolongation of the Purkinje fiber refractory period can be seen in patients taking class IA antiarrhythmic drugs and class III antiarrhythmics. Calcium-channel blockers have little or no direct effect on ventricular or His-Purkinje tract conduction or refractoriness and rely on a different effect on the cardiac conduction system for the treatment of arrhythmias.

B) INCORRECT:

A decrease in the bundle of His refractory period would not be expected with the administration of a drug that inhibits non-dihydropyridine calcium channels. Calcium-channel blockers have very little (if any) effect on ventricular or His-Purkinje tract conduction velocity or refractoriness.

C) INCORRECT:

Prolongation of ventricular myocyte repolarization can be caused by class III antiarrhythmic drugs, which act primarily by blocking cardiac potassium channels. This prolonged repolarization manifests as a prolonged QT interval on ECG. Class III antiarrhythmic drugs may also be used for atrial flutter, as well as for atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardias. However, calcium channel blockers rely on a different effect on the cardiac conduction system to prevent arrhythmias.

D) INCORRECT:

A decrease in myocardial action potential duration is seen in patients taking class IB antiarrhythmic drugs like lidocaine or mexiletine. These drugs have a weak blockade effect on voltage-gated sodium channels and are able to decrease action potential duration. Because agents in this class have minimal vagal, nodal, and atrial effects, they would not be effective options for decreasing sinoatrial or atrioventricular node automaticity. They are most effective at treating ventricular tachyarrhythmias.

E) CORRECT:

Prolongation of AV node repolarization is seen in patients taking class IV antiarrhythmic drugs like verapamil and diltiazem. Because the depolarization of nodal tissues (e.g., sinoatrial and atrioventricular nodes) is dependent upon the movement of calcium ions, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers primarily affect these tissues. The end result is prolonged AV node conduction time (decrease in conduction velocity) and refractory period (an increase in effective refractory period). This unique mechanism allows class IV antiarrhythmic drugs to effectively decrease SA/AV node automaticity in arrhythmias like atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation, and supraventricular tachycardias. Class IV antiarrhythmic drugs also increase the PR interval.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and ECG findings (narrow QRS complexes with an atrial rate of 240/min in a sawtooth pattern) are most consistent with atrial flutter. Verapamil and diltiazem (class IV antiarrhythmic drugs) are non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers that are commonly used as first-line therapy for atrial flutter.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of dizziness and intermittent episodes of heart palpitations for 5 days. During this time, she has also had one episode of syncope. An ECG shows absence of P waves and irregular RR intervals. Treatment with an antiarrhythmic drug is initiated. The effect of the drug on the cardiac action potential is shown. Which of the following cardiac ion channels is most likely targeted by this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Voltage-gated nonselective cation channels play an important role in cardiac pacemaking, with the most well-known example being the funny current. The funny current mediates the slow, spontaneous depolarization of myocytes during diastole, which accounts for the intrinsic pacemaking of the heart. This channel can be blocked pharmacologically by ivabradine, causing prolonged depolarization (phase 4 of the cardiac action potential) and reducing the intrinsic firing rate of the sinoatrial node. Blockage of these channels would not cause the slowed repolarization phase seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Voltage-gated sodium channels are the target of class I antiarrhythmic drugs, which can be further subdivided into class IA antiarrhythmics, class IB antiarrhythmics, and class IC antiarrhythmics. Although there are subtle differences in how drugs from each class affect specific aspects of the action potential, they all reduce or block conduction across cardiac myocytes by impairing phase 0 depolarization of the action potential. On graphs, this can be seen as a change in slope of the rapid depolarization phase. None of the class I antiarrhythmic agents reduce the rate of repolarization or prolong repolarization like the agent given to this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Voltage-gated potassium channels are the target of class III antiarrhythmic drugs like sotalol, amiodarone, dofetilide, and ibutilide. The markedly prolonged repolarization on the action potential curve here indicates potassium channel inhibition, which normally functions to restore resting cardiac myocyte membrane polarity. This effect prolongs the overall action potential and the effective refractory period, which explains the effectiveness of these drugs in treating tachyarrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation, atrial ﬂutter, and ventricular tachycardias.

D) INCORRECT:

Voltage-gated calcium channels are the target of class IV antiarrhythmic drugs like verapamil and diltiazem. These drugs work by inhibiting slow cardiac calcium channels, which slows conduction velocity in the sinoatrial node (SA node) and atrioventricular node (AV node). This causes the slope during phase 0 and 4 of the cardiac action potential to decrease. The markedly prolonged repolarization seen in the action potentials of the cardiac myocyte here suggests inhibition of another voltage-gated ion channel.
Image Description:

Compared to a unaffected action potential (faded line), the action potential of a pacemaker cell affected by a Class IV antiarrhythmic has a slower phase 4 depolarization (decreased slope), slower phase 0 depolarization (decreased slope), and an increased action potential duration.

E) INCORRECT:

Voltage-gated chloride channels are crucial for a host of biological processes. However, they do not play any major role in cardiac action potential generation. The markedly prolonged repolarization seen in the action potential of this patient suggests inhibition of another voltage-gated ion channel.
questions.hint: Absent P waves and irregular RR intervals on ECG are diagnostic of atrial fibrillation, which commonly manifests with intermittent palpitations and dizziness. Class III antiarrhythmic drugs can be used for acute termination and rhythm control, as they prolong repolarization and the effective refractory period.

questions.text: An investigator is comparing the risk of adverse effects among various antiarrhythmic medications. One of the drugs being studied primarily acts by blocking the outward flow of K+ during myocyte repolarization. Further investigation shows that the use of this drug is associated with a lower rate of ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and torsade de pointes when compared to similar drugs. Which of the following drugs is most likely being studied?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esmolol is a cardioselective β1-blocker with class II antiarrhythmic drug properties. It is used in the acute treatment of atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and supraventricular tachycardia. It inhibits β-adrenergic activation of adenylate cyclase and can delay conduction velocity. Unlike the drug being studied, esmolol has no effect on potassium channels.

B) INCORRECT:

Sotalol is a nonselective beta blocker with potent class II and class III antiarrhythmic properties. It is used in the treatment of supraventricular arrhythmias and ventricular arrhythmias. Like the drug being investigated, sotalol can also block potassium channels during myocyte repolarization, prolonging the action potential duration and effective refractory period. Unlike the drug being studied, sotalol has high arrhythmogenic potential and carries a high risk of inducing ventricular arrhythmias, such as torsades de pointes.

C) INCORRECT:

Mexiletine is a class IB antiarrhythmic drug that primarily acts by blocking sodium channels. It is typically used to treat ventricular arrhythmias (especially following myocardial infarction) and digitalis-induced cardiac arrhythmias. Unlike the drug being investigated, mexiletine has a minimal effect on the action potential duration and has no effect on potassium channel blockade.

D) INCORRECT:

Verapamil is a nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker with class IV antiarrhythmic drug properties. Class IV antiarrhythmic drugs prolong the repolarization of the AV node and can increase effective refractory periods. They are used in the treatment of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and multifocal atrial tachycardia. Unlike the drug under investigation, verapamil has no effect on potassium channels.

E) CORRECT:

Amiodarone (a class III antiarrhythmic drug) acts primarily by blocking outward potassium channels during myocyte repolarization, in addition to blocking sodium and calcium channels. Class III antiarrhythmic drugs prolong the action potential duration (APD) and effective refractory period (ERP), with no delay in conduction velocity. Like other class III agents, amiodarone can cause QT prolongation, although it carries a much lower risk of arrhythmia and torsades de pointes than other drugs of the same class.

Adverse events associated with amiodarone include thyroid and liver dysfunction, pulmonary fibrosis, peripheral neuropathy, corneal deposits, and photosensitivity.
questions.hint: This medication is a class III antiarrhythmic that increases effective refractory periods (ERP) and QT intervals. It is associated with thyroid abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman with well-controlled asthma presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations and shortness of breath. She underwent heart transplantation 5 years ago and currently takes an oral contraceptive.
Her heart rate is 160 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 96% while she is breathing ambient air.
An electrocardiogram shows a regular rhythm with a heart rate of 160 beats per minute and narrow QRS complexes. A previous electrocardiogram, performed when the patient was asymptomatic during a routine office visit, showed first-degree heart block with a normal heart rate. Carotid massage does not break the rhythm.
Which one of the following characteristics of this patient suggests that standard-dose adenosine should be avoided?

choices.text: The possibility of having coronary vasculopathy
The history of first-degree heart block

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenosine can be administered to patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenosine can be administered with caution (i.e., with continuous electrocardiographic monitoring) in patients with preexisting first-degree heart block, because development of high-grade block is rare in such patients and is transient when it occurs.

C) INCORRECT:

Adenosine is not contraindicated in patients who take oral contraceptives.

D) INCORRECT:

Adenosine can precipitate bronchospasm and, therefore, should be used cautiously in patients with severe obstructive pulmonary disease and avoided in those with active wheezing. In patients with a history of well-controlled asthma, adenosine can be used with caution.

E) CORRECT:

In patients who present with a narrow-complex tachycardia but without hemodynamic compromise, the options for terminating (as well as diagnosing) the rhythm include vagal maneuvers, intravenous adenosine, and intravenous calcium-channel blockers. Adenosine causes transient atrioventricular (AV) block and has been found to terminate supraventricular tachycardia in 60% to 80% of patients at a dose of 6 mg and in 90% to 95% of patients at a dose of 12 mg. AV block is often transient, but the risk for high-grade AV block or asystole is always present; therefore, careful electrocardiographic monitoring, plus the ready availability of resuscitative equipment and personnel, is essential when administering adenosine.

Because of the risk for high-grade AV block, standard-dose adenosine is contraindicated in patients who have second- or third-degree AV block or sick sinus syndrome but who do not have a pacemaker. Heart transplant recipients are particularly sensitive to the AV-blocking effects of adenosine, so the standard dose of the drug is contraindicated in these patients. A lower dose of adenosine (3 mg) is recommended in cardiac transplant recipients.

Key learning point: The medication that is typically used to treat supraventricular tachycardia, but that should be used at a reduced dose in patients with a history of a heart transplantation, is adenosine.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and palpitations for 3 hours. He has had similar episodes intermittently for 4 months. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Electrocardiography shows irregular narrow-complex tachycardia with no discernable P waves. Emergent electrical cardioversion is performed and the patient reverts to normal sinus rhythm. Pharmacotherapy with sotalol is begun. Which of the following is the most likely physiologic effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Decreased AV nodal conduction is a potent effect of all beta blockers, including sotalol, which has both class II antiarrhythmic (beta blocker) and class III antiarrhythmic (potassium-channel blocker) properties. As a consequence of sympathetic blockade (primarily β1 receptors), the conduction velocity through the AV node is reduced and the heart rate slows. Decreased AV nodal conduction would be evident on ECG as an increased PR interval. Class III antiarrhythmic effects of sotalol include increased myocyte action potential duration (due to delayed repolarization caused by decreased K+ efflux), increased effective refractory period, and prolonged QT interval.

Decreased AV nodal conduction is also caused by non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (class IV antiarrhythmics), class IC antiarrhythmics (e.g., flecainide, propafenone), digoxin, and adenosine.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased ventricular repolarization rate is seen with class IB antiarrhythmics (e.g., lidocaine, mexiletine), which are typically used to treat ventricular arrhythmias in patients with myocardial infarction, and digitalis-induced arrhythmias. Class III antiarrhythmic drugs, which block potassium channels in cardiac myocytes, would decrease rather than increase the ventricular repolarization rate.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased conduction in cardiac myocytes and Purkinje fibers is the mechanism by which sodium channel blockers (class I antiarrhythmics) function. By inhibiting the flow of sodium ions, the rapid depolarization phase (phase 0) of cardiac action potentials is slowed. Sotalol is not a class I antiarrhythmic and does not have a clinically apparent effect on conduction velocity in the Purkinje fibers.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased myocyte inotropy is caused by digoxin, which can be used to treat atrial fibrillation in patients with heart failure. Sotalol is an antiarrhythmic drug with the properties of a beta blocker (class II antiarrhythmic drug), and thus causes a decrease in inotropy.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperpolarization due to increased K+ efflux from myocytes is the mechanism of action of adenosine. Adenosine is used in the acute setting to terminate stable paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias (PSVT) such as AVNRT and AVRT, which are typically regular narrow complex tachycardias. Adenosine should not be used to treat atrial fibrillation (AF) because it worsens AF. This patient received sotalol, a class III antiarrhythmic drug, which would slow the rate of repolarization by decreasing K+ efflux from the myocyte.
questions.hint: Irregular narrow-complex tachycardia with no discernable P waves indicates atrial fibrillation. After multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation, this man was cardioverted and administered sotalol for continued rhythm control. Sotalol is a unique antiarrhythmic drug with both class II antiarrhythmic (beta blocker) and class III antiarrhythmic (potassium-channel blocker) properties.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with congestive heart failure is brought to the emergency department because of chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, and palpitations for 30 minutes. Electrocardiography shows a wide complex tachycardia with a P-wave rate of 105/min, an R-wave rate of 130/min, and no apparent relation between the two. Intravenous pharmacotherapy is initiated with a drug that prolongs the QRS and QT intervals. The patient was most likely treated with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carvedilol is a nonselective beta blocker/alpha 1 blocker and a class II antiarrhythmic. It blocks β1, β2, and α1 receptors on cardiac myocytes. The alpha blockade decreases peripheral vascular resistance, resulting in an antihypertensive effect. Beta inhibition leads to decreased heart rate (increased PR interval) and contractility. Carvedilol does not impact the QT interval or QRS duration.

B) INCORRECT:

Verapamil is a class IV antiarrhythmic. These drugs are used for controlling ventricular rate in supraventricular tachycardia and act on calcium-dependent cardiac cells, such as those in the AV node. Class IV drugs reduce inward calcium current during the AP and phase 4. As a result, conduction velocity through the AV node is decreased and the refractory period is prolonged, which increases the PR interval. Verapamil does not have an effect on QRS or QT duration, though.

C) INCORRECT:

Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic. While these drugs are powerful depressants of the sodium current, they have no effect on ventricular AP duration or the QT interval.

D) INCORRECT:

Lidocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic. While all class I drugs slow conduction through the fast-inward sodium current (INa), class IB drugs selectively affect ischemic or depolarized tissue. They have little effect on atrial tissue and do not reduce the Phase 3 potassium current (IK). This results in a shortened action potential duration but prolonged effective refractory period. These drugs would not be expected to increase the QRS duration or the QT interval.

E) CORRECT:

Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic agent used to treat or prevent ventricular arrhythmias. All class I drugs slow conduction by blocking the voltage-gated sodium channels. This causes the phase 0 depolarization rate of the cardiac action potential to decrease. This occurs in a “use-dependent” fashion: at higher heart rates, the sodium channel block intensifies, while the opposite is true at lower heart rates. Class IA drugs also reduce phase 3 potassium current (IK) and prolong the effective refractory period. The overall effect of quinidine, as seen on this patient's ECG is prolongation of the QT and QRS durations.
questions.hint: The drug administered to this patient acts to block cardiac sodium channels and prolongs the action potential.

questions.text: You are seeing a 57-year-old man in the emergency department with a 3-hour history of shortness of breath and palpitations. He reports having similar episodes intermittently over the past 4 months. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Electrocardiography reveals an irregular narrow-complex tachycardia without discernable P waves. Emergent electrical cardioversion is performed, restoring normal sinus rhythm. Pharmacotherapy with sotalol is initiated. Which one of the following is the most likely physiologic effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperpolarization due to increased K+ efflux from myocytes is the mechanism of action of adenosine. Adenosine is used in the acute setting to terminate stable paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias (PSVT) such as AVNRT and AVRT, which are typically regular narrow complex tachycardias. Adenosine should not be used to treat atrial fibrillation (AF) because it worsens AF. This patient received sotalol, a class III antiarrhythmic drug, which would slow the rate of repolarization by decreasing K+ efflux from the myocyte.

B) CORRECT:

Decreased AV nodal conduction is a potent effect of all beta blockers, including sotalol, which has both class II antiarrhythmic (beta blocker) and class III antiarrhythmic (potassium-channel blocker) properties. As a consequence of sympathetic blockade (primarily β1 receptors), the conduction velocity through the AV node is reduced and the heart rate slows. Decreased AV nodal conduction would be evident on ECG as an increased PR interval. Class III antiarrhythmic effects of sotalol include increased myocyte action potential duration (due to delayed repolarization caused by decreased K+ efflux), increased effective refractory period, and prolonged QT interval.

Decreased AV nodal conduction is also caused by non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (class IV antiarrhythmics), class IC antiarrhythmics (e.g., flecainide, propafenone), digoxin, and adenosine.

Key learning point: Beta blockers decrease AV nodal conduction, leading to a slower heart rate and increased PR interval on ECG.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased myocyte inotropy is caused by digoxin, which can be used to treat atrial fibrillation in patients with heart failure. Sotalol is an antiarrhythmic drug with the properties of a beta blocker (class II antiarrhythmic drug), and thus causes a decrease in inotropy.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased conduction in cardiac myocytes and Purkinje fibers is the mechanism by which sodium channel blockers (class I antiarrhythmics) function. By inhibiting the flow of sodium ions, the rapid depolarization phase (phase 0) of cardiac action potentials is slowed. Sotalol is not a class I antiarrhythmic and does not have a clinically apparent effect on conduction velocity in the Purkinje fibers.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased ventricular repolarization rate is seen with class IB antiarrhythmics (e.g., lidocaine, mexiletine), which are typically used to treat ventricular arrhythmias in patients with myocardial infarction, and digitalis-induced arrhythmias. Class III antiarrhythmic drugs, which block potassium channels in cardiac myocytes, would decrease rather than increase the ventricular repolarization rate.
questions.hint: Irregular narrow-complex tachycardia with no discernable P waves indicates atrial fibrillation. After multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation, this man was cardioverted and administered sotalol for continued rhythm control. Sotalol is a unique antiarrhythmic drug with both class II antiarrhythmic (beta blocker) and class III antiarrhythmic (potassium-channel blocker) properties.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with heart failure presents with palpitations for 2 hours. Vital signs are BP, 80/60; P, 165; R, 18; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). The patient reports feeling lightheaded. ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenosine can be used to treat stable supraventricular tachycardia. This patient is unstable and needs more immediate management.

B) INCORRECT:

Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker and can be used in stable supraventricular tachycardia if adenosine is ineffective. This patient is unstable and needs more immediate management.

C) INCORRECT:

Defibrillation is used to treat ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia. This patient has a pulse and a regular narrow-complex tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic agent and can be used in stable supraventricular tachycardia if adenosine, calcium channel blockers, and beta blockers are ineffective. This patient is unstable and needs more immediate management.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The ECG shows a narrow-complex tachycardia, and the patient is unstable, as evidenced by hypotension. Urgent synchronized electrical cardioversion is indicated.
